data.name: AvoidAsyncVoidTitle
data.value: Avoid Async Void

data.name: AvoidAsyncVoidDescription
data.value: #N/A

data.name: AvoidAsyncVoidMessage
data.value: Avoid Async Void

data.name: AsyncMethodNamesShouldEndInAsyncTitle
data.value: Async Method Names Should End in Async

data.name: AsyncMethodNamesShouldEndInAsyncDescription
data.value: #N/A

data.name: AsyncMethodNamesShouldEndInAsyncMessage
data.value: Async Method Names Should End in Async

data.name: DonTPassAsyncLambdasAsVoidReturningDelegateTypesTitle
data.value: Don't Pass Async Lambdas as Void Returning Delegate Types

data.name: DonTPassAsyncLambdasAsVoidReturningDelegateTypesDescription
data.value: #N/A

data.name: DonTPassAsyncLambdasAsVoidReturningDelegateTypesMessage
data.value: Don't Pass Async Lambdas as Void Returning Delegate Types

data.name: DonTStoreAsyncLambdasAsVoidReturningDelegateTypesTitle
data.value: Don't Store Async Lambdas as Void Returning Delegate Types

data.name: DonTStoreAsyncLambdasAsVoidReturningDelegateTypesDescription
data.value: #N/A

data.name: DonTStoreAsyncLambdasAsVoidReturningDelegateTypesMessage
data.value: Don't Store Async Lambdas as Void Returning Delegate Types

data.name: PropagateCancellationTokensWhenPossibleTitle
data.value: Propagate CancellationTokens When Possible

data.name: PropagateCancellationTokensWhenPossibleDescription
data.value: #N/A

data.name: PropagateCancellationTokensWhenPossibleMessage
data.value: Propagate CancellationTokens When Possible

data.name: DonTMixBlockingAndAsyncTitle
data.value: Don't Mix Blocking and Async

data.name: DonTMixBlockingAndAsyncDescription
data.value: #N/A

data.name: DonTMixBlockingAndAsyncMessage
data.value: Don't Mix Blocking and Async

data.name: TypesThatOwnDisposableFieldsShouldBeDisposableTitle
data.value: Types that own disposable fields should be disposable

data.name: TypesThatOwnDisposableFieldsShouldBeDisposableDescription
data.value: A class declares and implements an instance field that is a System.IDisposable type, and the class does not implement IDisposable. A class that declares an IDisposable field indirectly owns an unmanaged resource and should implement the IDisposable interface.

data.name: TypesThatOwnDisposableFieldsShouldBeDisposableMessageDependsOnFix
data.value: Implement IDisposable on {0} because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: {1}. If {0} has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.

data.name: TypesThatOwnDisposableFieldsShouldBeDisposableMessageNonBreaking
data.value: Type '{0}' owns disposable fields but is not disposable

data.name: UseGenericEventHandlerInstancesTitle
data.value: Use generic event handler instances

data.name: UseGenericEventHandlerInstancesDescription
data.value: A type contains a delegate that returns void, whose signature contains two parameters (the first an object and the second a type that is assignable to EventArgs), and the containing assembly targets Microsoft .NET Framework?2.0.

data.name: UseGenericEventHandlerInstancesMessageVB
data.value: Visual Basic generates EventHandler delegates for events that use the following pattern: Event MyEvent(ByVal Sender As Object, ByVal e as MyEventArgs). Change the event that defines EventHandler {0} to use EventHandler<T> by defining the event type explicitly, e.g. Event MyEvent As EventHandler(Of MyEventArgs).

data.name: UseGenericEventHandlerInstancesMessageDefault
data.value: Remove {0} and replace its usage with EventHandler<T>

data.name: EnumsShouldHaveZeroValueTitle
data.value: Enums should have zero value

data.name: EnumsShouldHaveZeroValueDescription
data.value: The default value of an uninitialized enumeration, just as other value types, is zero. A nonflags-attributed enumeration should define a member by using the value of zero so that the default value is a valid value of the enumeration. If an enumeration that has the FlagsAttribute attribute applied defines a zero-valued member, its name should be ""None"" to indicate that no values have been set in the enumeration.

data.name: EnumsShouldHaveZeroValueMessageFlagsRename
data.value: In enum {0}, change the name of {1} to 'None'.

data.name: EnumsShouldHaveZeroValueMessageFlagsMultipleZeros
data.value: Remove all members that have the value zero from {0} except for one member that is named 'None'.

data.name: EnumsShouldHaveZeroValueMessageNotFlagsNoZeroValue
data.value: Add a member to {0} that has a value of zero with a suggested name of 'None'.

data.name: AbstractTypesShouldNotHaveConstructorsTitle
data.value: Abstract types should not have constructors

data.name: AbstractTypesShouldNotHaveConstructorsDescription
data.value: Constructors on abstract types can be called only by derived types. Because public constructors create instances of a type, and you cannot create instances of an abstract type, an abstract type that has a public constructor is incorrectly designed.

data.name: AbstractTypesShouldNotHaveConstructorsMessage
data.value: Abstract type {0} should not have constructors

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithClsCompliantTitle
data.value: Mark assemblies with CLSCompliant

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithClsCompliantDescription
data.value: The Common Language Specification (CLS) defines naming restrictions, data types, and rules to which assemblies must conform if they will be used across programming languages. Good design dictates that all assemblies explicitly indicate CLS compliance by using CLSCompliantAttribute . If this attribute is not present on an assembly, the assembly is not compliant.

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithClsCompliantMessage
data.value: Mark assemblies with CLSCompliant

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithAssemblyVersionTitle
data.value: Mark assemblies with assembly version

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithAssemblyVersionDescription
data.value: The .NET Framework uses the version number to uniquely identify an assembly, and to bind to types in strongly named assemblies. The version number is used together with version and publisher policy. By default, applications run only with the assembly version with which they were built.

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithAssemblyVersionMessage
data.value: Mark assemblies with assembly version

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithComVisibleTitle
data.value: Mark assemblies with ComVisible

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithComVisibleDescription
data.value: ComVisibleAttribute determines how COM clients access managed code. Good design dictates that assemblies explicitly indicate COM visibility. COM visibility can be set for the whole assembly and then overridden for individual types and type members. If this attribute is not present, the contents of the assembly are visible to COM clients.

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithComVisibleMessageNoAttribute
data.value: Because {0} exposes externally visible types, mark it with ComVisible(false) at the assembly level and then mark all types within the assembly that should be exposed to COM clients with ComVisible(true).

data.name: MarkAssembliesWithComVisibleMessageAttributeTrue
data.value: Consider changing the ComVisible attribute on {0} to false, and opting in at the type level.

data.name: MarkAttributesWithAttributeUsageTitle
data.value: Mark attributes with AttributeUsageAttribute

data.name: MarkAttributesWithAttributeUsageDescription
data.value: When you define a custom attribute, mark it by using AttributeUsageAttribute to indicate where in the source code the custom attribute can be applied. The meaning and intended usage of an attribute will determine its valid locations in code.

data.name: MarkAttributesWithAttributeUsageMessageDefault
data.value: Specify AttributeUsage on {0}.

data.name: MarkAttributesWithAttributeUsageMessageInherited
data.value: Even though attribute {0} inherits AttributeUsage from its base type, you should consider explicitly specifying AttributeUsage on the type to improve code readability and documentation.

data.name: DefineAccessorsForAttributeArgumentsTitle
data.value: Define accessors for attribute arguments

data.name: DefineAccessorsForAttributeArgumentsDescription
data.value: Attributes can define mandatory arguments that must be specified when you apply the attribute to a target. These are also known as positional arguments because they are supplied to attribute constructors as positional parameters. For every mandatory argument, the attribute should also provide a corresponding read-only property so that the value of the argument can be retrieved at execution time. Attributes can also define optional arguments, which are also known as named arguments. These arguments are supplied to attribute constructors by name and should have a corresponding read/write property.

data.name: DefineAccessorsForAttributeArgumentsMessageDefault
data.value: Add a public read-only property accessor for positional argument {0} of Attribute {1}.

data.name: DefineAccessorsForAttributeArgumentsMessageRemoveSetter
data.value: Remove the property setter from {0} or reduce its accessibility because it corresponds to positional argument {1}.

data.name: DefineAccessorsForAttributeArgumentsMessageIncreaseVisibility
data.value: If {0} is the property accessor for positional argument {1}, make it public.

data.name: UsePropertiesWhereAppropriateTitle
data.value: Use properties where appropriate

data.name: UsePropertiesWhereAppropriateDescription
data.value: A public or protected method has a name that starts with ""Get"", takes no parameters, and returns a value that is not an array. The method might be a good candidate to become a property.

data.name: UsePropertiesWhereAppropriateMessage
data.value: Use properties where appropriate

data.name: MarkEnumsWithFlagsTitle
data.value: Mark enums with FlagsAttribute

data.name: MarkEnumsWithFlagsDescription
data.value: An enumeration is a value type that defines a set of related named constants. Apply FlagsAttribute to an enumeration when its named constants can be meaningfully combined.

data.name: MarkEnumsWithFlagsMessage
data.value: Mark enums with FlagsAttribute

data.name: InterfaceMethodsShouldBeCallableByChildTypesTitle
data.value: Interface methods should be callable by child types

data.name: InterfaceMethodsShouldBeCallableByChildTypesDescription
data.value: An unsealed externally visible type provides an explicit method implementation of a public interface and does not provide an alternative externally visible method that has the same name.

data.name: InterfaceMethodsShouldBeCallableByChildTypesMessage
data.value: Interface methods should be callable by child types

data.name: OverrideMethodsOnComparableTypesTitle
data.value: Override methods on comparable types

data.name: OverrideMethodsOnComparableTypesDescription
data.value: A public or protected type implements the System.IComparable interface. It does not override Object.Equals nor does it overload the language-specific operator for equality, inequality, less than, or greater than.

data.name: OverrideMethodsOnComparableTypesMessageEquals
data.value: {0} should override Equals since it implements IComparable.

data.name: OverrideMethodsOnComparableTypesMessageOperator
data.value: {0} should define operator '{1}' since it implements IComparable.

data.name: MovePInvokesToNativeMethodsClassTitle
data.value: Move pinvokes to native methods class

data.name: MovePInvokesToNativeMethodsClassDescription
data.value: Platform Invocation methods, such as those that are marked by using the System.Runtime.InteropServices.DllImportAttribute attribute, or methods that are defined by using the Declare keyword in Visual Basic, access unmanaged code. These methods should be of the NativeMethods, SafeNativeMethods, or UnsafeNativeMethods class.

data.name: MovePInvokesToNativeMethodsClassMessage
data.value: Move pinvokes to native methods class

data.name: IdentifiersShouldDifferByMoreThanCaseTitle
data.value: Identifiers should differ by more than case

data.name: IdentifiersShouldDifferByMoreThanCaseDescription
data.value: Identifiers for namespaces, types, members, and parameters cannot differ only by case because languages that target the common language runtime are not required to be case-sensitive.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldDifferByMoreThanCaseMessage
data.value: Names of '{0}' and '{1}' should differ by more than case.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldHaveCorrectPrefixTitle
data.value: Identifiers should have correct prefix

data.name: IdentifiersShouldHaveCorrectPrefixDescription
data.value: The name of an externally visible interface does not start with an uppercase ""I"". The name of a generic type parameter on an externally visible type or method does not start with an uppercase ""T"".

data.name: IdentifiersShouldHaveCorrectPrefixMessageInterface
data.value: Prefix interface name {0} with 'I'.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldHaveCorrectPrefixMessageTypeParameter
data.value: Prefix generic type parameter name {0} with 'T'.

data.name: NonConstantFieldsShouldNotBeVisibleTitle
data.value: Non-constant fields should not be visible

data.name: NonConstantFieldsShouldNotBeVisibleDescription
data.value: Static fields that are neither constants nor read-only are not thread-safe. Access to such a field must be carefully controlled and requires advanced programming techniques to synchronize access to the class object.

data.name: NonConstantFieldsShouldNotBeVisibleMessage
data.value: Non-constant fields should not be visible

data.name: DoNotMarkEnumsWithFlagsTitle
data.value: Do not mark enums with FlagsAttribute

data.name: DoNotMarkEnumsWithFlagsDescription
data.value: An externally visible enumeration is marked by using FlagsAttribute, and it has one or more values that are not powers of two or a combination of the other defined values on the enumeration.

data.name: DoNotMarkEnumsWithFlagsMessage
data.value: Do not mark enums with FlagsAttribute

data.name: DoNotDecreaseInheritedMemberVisibilityTitle
data.value: Do not decrease inherited member visibility

data.name: DoNotDecreaseInheritedMemberVisibilityDescription
data.value: You should not change the access modifier for inherited members. Changing an inherited member to private does not prevent callers from accessing the base class implementation of the method.

data.name: DoNotDecreaseInheritedMemberVisibilityMessage
data.value: Do not decrease inherited member visibility

data.name: OperatorOverloadsHaveNamedAlternatesTitle
data.value: Operator overloads have named alternates

data.name: OperatorOverloadsHaveNamedAlternatesDescription
data.value: An operator overload was detected, and the expected named alternative method was not found. The named alternative member provides access to the same functionality as the operator and is provided for developers who program in languages that do not support overloaded operators.

data.name: OperatorOverloadsHaveNamedAlternatesMessageDefault
data.value: Provide a method named '{0}' as a friendly alternate for operator {1}.

data.name: OperatorOverloadsHaveNamedAlternatesMessageProperty
data.value: Provide a property named '{0}' as a friendly alternate for operator {1}.

data.name: OperatorOverloadsHaveNamedAlternatesMessageMultiple
data.value: Provide a method named '{0}' or '{1}' as an alternate for operator {2}.

data.name: OperatorOverloadsHaveNamedAlternatesMessageVisibility
data.value: Mark {0} as public because it is a friendly alternate for operator {1}.

data.name: OperatorsShouldHaveSymmetricalOverloadsTitle
data.value: Operators should have symmetrical overloads

data.name: OperatorsShouldHaveSymmetricalOverloadsDescription
data.value: A type implements the equality or inequality operator and does not implement the opposite operator.

data.name: OperatorsShouldHaveSymmetricalOverloadsMessage
data.value: Operators should have symmetrical overloads

data.name: CollectionPropertiesShouldBeReadOnlyTitle
data.value: Collection properties should be read only

data.name: CollectionPropertiesShouldBeReadOnlyDescription
data.value: A writable collection property allows a user to replace the collection with a different collection. A read-only property stops the collection from being replaced but still allows the individual members to be set.

data.name: CollectionPropertiesShouldBeReadOnlyMessage
data.value: Collection properties should be read only

data.name: OverloadOperatorEqualsOnOverridingValueTypeEqualsTitle
data.value: Overload operator equals on overriding value type Equals

data.name: OverloadOperatorEqualsOnOverridingValueTypeEqualsDescription
data.value: In most programming languages there is no default implementation of the equality operator (==) for value types. If your programming language supports operator overloads, you should consider implementing the equality operator. Its behavior should be identical to that of Equals

data.name: OverloadOperatorEqualsOnOverridingValueTypeEqualsMessage
data.value: Overload operator equals on overriding value type Equals

data.name: PassSystemUriObjectsInsteadOfStringsTitle
data.value: Pass system uri objects instead of strings

data.name: PassSystemUriObjectsInsteadOfStringsDescription
data.value: A call is made to a method that has a string parameter whose name contains "uri", "URI", "urn", "URN", "url", or "URL". The declaring type of the method contains a corresponding method overload that has a System.Uri parameter.

data.name: PassSystemUriObjectsInsteadOfStringsMessage
data.value: Pass system uri objects instead of strings

data.name: ImplementIEquatableWhenOverridingObjectEqualsTitle
data.value: Type {0} should implement IEquatable<T> because it overrides Equals

data.name: ImplementIEquatableWhenOverridingObjectEqualsMessage
data.value: Implement IEquatable when overriding Object.Equals

data.name: CancellationTokenParametersMustComeLastTitle
data.value: CancellationToken parameters must come last

data.name: CancellationTokenParametersMustComeLastMessage
data.value: Method '{0}' should take CancellationToken as the last parameter

data.name: ConstructorMakeNoninheritableBaseClassInheritableTitle
data.value: Constructor make noninheritable base class inheritable

data.name: ConstructorMakeNoninheritableBaseClassInheritableDescription
data.value: When a base class is noninheritable because its constructor is internal, a derived class should not make it inheritable by having a public or protected constructor.

data.name: ConstructorMakeNoninheritableBaseClassInheritableMessage
data.value: Constructor make noninheritable base class inheritable

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainTypeNamesTitle
data.value: Identifier contains type name

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainTypeNamesDescription
data.value: Names of parameters and members are better used to communicate their meaning than to describe their type, which is expected to be provided by development tools. For names of members, if a data type name must be used, use a language-independent name instead of a language-specific one.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainTypeNamesMessage
data.value: Identifier '{0}' contains type name

data.name: CreatePropertyAccessorForParameter
data.value: Create a property accessor.

data.name: MakeGetterPublic
data.value: Make the getter of the property public

data.name: MakeSetterNonPublic
data.value: Make the setter of the property non-public

data.name: AddAssemblyLevelComVisibleFalse
data.value: Because {0} exposes externally visible types, mark it with ComVisible(false) at the assembly level and then mark all types within the assembly that should be exposed to COM clients with ComVisible(true).

data.name: ChangeAssemblyLevelComVisibleToFalse
data.value: Consider changing the ComVisible attribute on {0} to false, and opting in at the type level.

data.name: ImplementComparable
data.value: Implement Equality and Comparison methods and operators

data.name: ImplementIDisposableInterface
data.value: Implement IDisposable Interface

data.name: DoNotMarkEnumsWithFlagsCodeFix
data.value: Remove FlagsAttribute from enum.

data.name: MarkEnumsWithFlagsCodeFix
data.value: Apply FlagsAttribute to enum.

data.name: EnumsShouldZeroValueFlagsMultipleZeroCodeFix
data.value: Remove all members that have the value zero except for one member that is named 'None'.

data.name: EnumsShouldZeroValueFlagsRenameCodeFix
data.value: Rename zero-valued enum field to 'None'.

data.name: EnumsShouldZeroValueNotFlagsNoZeroValueCodeFix
data.value: Add a zero-valued member 'None' to enum.

data.name: AbstractTypesShouldNotHavePublicConstructorsCodeFix
data.value: Change the accessibility of public constructors to protected.

data.name: DoNotDeclareStaticMembersOnGenericTypesTitle
data.value: Do not declare static members on generic types

data.name: DoNotDeclareStaticMembersOnGenericTypesDescription
data.value: When a static member of a generic type is called, the type argument must be specified for the type. When a generic instance member that does not support inference is called, the type argument must be specified for the member. In these two cases, the syntax for specifying the type argument is different and easily confused.

data.name: DoNotDeclareStaticMembersOnGenericTypesMessage
data.value: Do not declare static members on generic types

data.name: CollectionsShouldImplementGenericInterfaceTitle
data.value: Collections should implement generic interface

data.name: CollectionsShouldImplementGenericInterfaceDescription
data.value: To broaden the usability of a collection, implement one of the generic collection interfaces. Then the collection can be used to populate generic collection types.

data.name: CollectionsShouldImplementGenericInterfaceMessage
data.value: Collections should implement generic interface

data.name: EnumStorageShouldBeInt32Title
data.value: Enum Storage should be Int32

data.name: EnumStorageShouldBeInt32Description
data.value: An enumeration is a value type that defines a set of related named constants. By default, the System.Int32 data type is used to store the constant value. Although you can change this underlying type, it is not required or recommended for most scenarios.

data.name: EnumStorageShouldBeInt32MessageNotInt32
data.value: If possible, make the underlying type of {0} System.Int32 instead of {1}.

data.name: EnumStorageShouldBeInt32MessageNotIntegral
data.value: If possible, make the underlying type of {0} Int32 instead of {1}. Otherwise consider Byte, Int16, or Int64.

data.name: UseEventsWhereAppropriateTitle
data.value: Use events where appropriate

data.name: UseEventsWhereAppropriateDescription
data.value: This rule detects methods that have names that ordinarily would be used for events. If a method is called in response to a clearly defined state change, the method should be invoked by an event handler. Objects that call the method should raise events instead of calling the method directly.

data.name: UseEventsWhereAppropriateMessage
data.value: Use events where appropriate

data.name: ImplementStandardExceptionConstructorsTitle
data.value: Implement standard exception constructors

data.name: ImplementStandardExceptionConstructorsDescription
data.value: Failure to provide the full set of constructors can make it difficult to correctly handle exceptions.

data.name: ImplementStandardExceptionConstructorsMessageMissingConstructor
data.value: Add the following constructor to {0}: {1}.

data.name: ImplementStandardExceptionConstructorsMessageAccessibility
data.value: Change the accessibility of {0} to {1}.

data.name: NestedTypesShouldNotBeVisibleTitle
data.value: Nested types should not be visible

data.name: NestedTypesShouldNotBeVisibleDescription
data.value: A nested type is a type that is declared in the scope of another type. Nested types are useful to encapsulate private implementation details of the containing type. Used for this purpose, nested types should not be externally visible.

data.name: NestedTypesShouldNotBeVisibleMessageDefault
data.value: Do not nest type {0}. Alternatively, change its accessibility so that it is not externally visible.

data.name: NestedTypesShouldNotBeVisibleMessageVisualBasicModule
data.value: Do not nest type {0}. Alternatively, change its accessibility so that it is not externally visible. If this type is defined in a Visual Basic Module, it will be considered a nested type to other .NET languages. In that case, consider moving the type outside of the Module.

data.name: AvoidEmptyInterfacesTitle
data.value: Avoid empty interfaces

data.name: AvoidEmptyInterfacesDescription
data.value: Interfaces define members that provide a behavior or usage contract. The functionality that is described by the interface can be adopted by any type, regardless of where the type appears in the inheritance hierarchy. A type implements an interface by providing implementations for the members of the interface. An empty interface does not define any members; therefore, it does not define a contract that can be implemented.

data.name: AvoidEmptyInterfacesMessage
data.value: Avoid empty interfaces

data.name: ProvideObsoleteAttributeMessageTitle
data.value: Provide ObsoleteAttribute message

data.name: ProvideObsoleteAttributeMessageDescription
data.value: A type or member is marked by using a System.ObsoleteAttribute attribute that does not have its ObsoleteAttribute.Message property specified. When a type or member that is marked by using ObsoleteAttribute is compiled, the Message property of the attribute is displayed. This gives the user information about the obsolete type or member.

data.name: ProvideObsoleteAttributeMessageMessage
data.value: Provide a message for the ObsoleteAttribute that marks {0} as Obsolete

data.name: PropertiesShouldNotBeWriteOnlyTitle
data.value: Properties should not be write only

data.name: PropertiesShouldNotBeWriteOnlyDescription
data.value: Although it is acceptable and often necessary to have a read-only property, the design guidelines prohibit the use of write-only properties. This is because letting a user set a value, and then preventing the user from viewing that value, does not provide any security. Also, without read access, the state of shared objects cannot be viewed, which limits their usefulness.

data.name: PropertiesShouldNotBeWriteOnlyMessageAddGetter
data.value: Because property {0} is write-only, either add a property getter with an accessibility that is greater than or equal to its setter or convert this property into a method.

data.name: PropertiesShouldNotBeWriteOnlyMessageMakeMoreAccessible
data.value: Because the property getter for {0} is less visible than its setter, either increase the accessibility of its getter or decrease the accessibility of its setter.

data.name: DeclareTypesInNamespacesTitle
data.value: Declare types in namespaces

data.name: DeclareTypesInNamespacesDescription
data.value: Types are declared in namespaces to prevent name collisions and as a way to organize related types in an object hierarchy.

data.name: DeclareTypesInNamespacesMessage
data.value: Declare types in namespaces

data.name: DoNotDeclareVisibleInstanceFieldsTitle
data.value: Do not declare visible instance fields

data.name: DoNotDeclareVisibleInstanceFieldsDescription
data.value: The primary use of a field should be as an implementation detail. Fields should be private or internal and should be exposed by using properties.

data.name: DoNotDeclareVisibleInstanceFieldsMessage
data.value: Do not declare visible instance fields

data.name: UriParametersShouldNotBeStringsTitle
data.value: Uri parameters should not be strings

data.name: UriParametersShouldNotBeStringsDescription
data.value: If a method takes a string representation of a URI, a corresponding overload should be provided that takes an instance of the URI class, which provides these services in a safe and secure manner.

data.name: UriParametersShouldNotBeStringsMessage
data.value: Uri parameters should not be strings

data.name: UriReturnValuesShouldNotBeStringsTitle
data.value: Uri return values should not be strings

data.name: UriReturnValuesShouldNotBeStringsDescription
data.value: This rule assumes that the method returns a URI. A string representation of a URI is prone to parsing and encoding errors, and can lead to security vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class provides these services in a safe and secure manner.

data.name: UriReturnValuesShouldNotBeStringsMessage
data.value: Uri return values should not be strings

data.name: UriPropertiesShouldNotBeStringsTitle
data.value: Uri properties should not be strings

data.name: UriPropertiesShouldNotBeStringsDescription
data.value: This rule assumes that the property represents a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI). A string representation of a URI is prone to parsing and encoding errors, and can lead to security vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class provides these services in a safe and secure manner.

data.name: UriPropertiesShouldNotBeStringsMessage
data.value: Uri properties should not be strings

data.name: ImplementIDisposableCorrectlyTitle
data.value: Implement IDisposable Correctly

data.name: ImplementIDisposableCorrectlyDescription
data.value: All IDisposable types should implement the Dispose pattern correctly.

data.name: ImplementIDisposableCorrectlyMessageIDisposableReimplementation
data.value: Remove IDisposable from the list of interfaces implemented by {0} and override the base class Dispose implementation instead.

data.name: ImplementIDisposableCorrectlyMessageFinalizeOverride
data.value: Remove the finalizer from type {0}, override Dispose(bool disposing), and put the finalization logic in the code path where 'disposing' is false.

data.name: ImplementIDisposableCorrectlyMessageDisposeOverride
data.value: Remove {0}, override Dispose(bool disposing), and put the dispose logic in the code path where 'disposing' is true.

data.name: ImplementIDisposableCorrectlyMessageDisposeSignature
data.value: Ensure that {0} is declared as public and sealed.

data.name: ImplementIDisposableCorrectlyMessageRenameDispose
data.value: Rename {0} to 'Dispose' and ensure that it is declared as public and sealed.

data.name: ImplementIDisposableCorrectlyMessageDisposeBoolSignature
data.value: Ensure that {0} is declared as protected, virtual, and unsealed.

data.name: ImplementIDisposableCorrectlyMessageDisposeImplementation
data.value: Modify {0} so that it calls Dispose(true), then calls GC.SuppressFinalize on the current object instance ('this' or 'Me' in Visual Basic), and then returns.

data.name: ImplementIDisposableCorrectlyMessageFinalizeImplementation
data.value: Modify {0} so that it calls Dispose(false) and then returns.

data.name: ImplementIDisposableCorrectlyMessageProvideDisposeBool
data.value: Provide an overridable implementation of Dispose(bool) on {0} or mark the type as sealed. A call to Dispose(false) should only clean up native resources. A call to Dispose(true) should clean up both managed and native resources.

data.name: ExceptionsShouldBePublicTitle
data.value: Exceptions should be public

data.name: ExceptionsShouldBePublicDescription
data.value: An internal exception is visible only inside its own internal scope. After the exception falls outside the internal scope, only the base exception can be used to catch the exception. If the internal exception is inherited from T:System.Exception, T:System.SystemException, or T:System.ApplicationException, the external code will not have sufficient information to know what to do with the exception.

data.name: ExceptionsShouldBePublicMessage
data.value: Exceptions should be public

data.name: DoNotRaiseExceptionsInUnexpectedLocationsTitle
data.value: Do not raise exceptions in unexpected locations

data.name: DoNotRaiseExceptionsInUnexpectedLocationsDescription
data.value: A method that is not expected to throw exceptions throws an exception.

data.name: DoNotRaiseExceptionsInUnexpectedLocationsMessagePropertyGetter
data.value: {0} creates an exception of type {1}, an exception type that should not be raised in a property. If this exception instance might be raised, use a different exception type, convert this property into a method, or change this property's logic so that it no longer raises an exception.

data.name: DoNotRaiseExceptionsInUnexpectedLocationsMessageHasAllowedExceptions
data.value: {0} creates an exception of type {1}, an exception type that should not be raised in this type of method. If this exception instance might be raised, either use a different exception type or change this method's logic so that it no longer raises an exception.

data.name: DoNotRaiseExceptionsInUnexpectedLocationsMessageNoAllowedExceptions
data.value: {0} creates an exception of type {1}. Exceptions should not be raised in this type of method. If this exception instance might be raised, change this method's logic so it no longer raises an exception.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainUnderscoresTitle
data.value: Identifiers should not contain underscores

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainUnderscoresDescription
data.value: By convention, identifier names do not contain the underscore (_) character. This rule checks namespaces, types, members, and parameters.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainUnderscoresMessageAssembly
data.value: Remove the underscores from assembly name {0}.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainUnderscoresMessageNamespace
data.value: Remove the underscores from namespace name '{0}'.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainUnderscoresMessageType
data.value: Remove the underscores from type name {0}.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainUnderscoresMessageMember
data.value: Remove the underscores from member name {0}.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainUnderscoresMessageTypeTypeParameter
data.value: On type {0}, remove the underscores from generic type parameter name {1}.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainUnderscoresMessageMethodTypeParameter
data.value: On method {0}, remove the underscores from generic type parameter name {1}.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainUnderscoresMessageMemberParameter
data.value: In member {0}, remove the underscores from parameter name {1}.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotContainUnderscoresMessageDelegateParameter
data.value: In delegate {0}, remove the underscores from parameter name {1}.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldHaveCorrectSuffixTitle
data.value: Identifiers should have correct suffix

data.name: IdentifiersShouldHaveCorrectSuffixDescription
data.value: By convention, the names of types that extend certain base types or that implement certain interfaces, or types that are derived from these types, have a suffix that is associated with the base type or interface.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldHaveCorrectSuffixMessageDefault
data.value: Rename {0} to end in '{1}'.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldHaveCorrectSuffixMessageSpecialCollection
data.value: Rename {0} to end in either 'Collection' or '{1}'.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotHaveIncorrectSuffixTitle
data.value: Identifiers should not have incorrect suffix

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotHaveIncorrectSuffixDescription
data.value: By convention, only the names of types that extend certain base types or that implement certain interfaces, or types that are derived from these types, should end with specific reserved suffixes. Other type names should not use these reserved suffixes.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotHaveIncorrectSuffixMessageTypeNoAlternate
data.value: Rename type name {0} so that it does not end in '{1}'.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotHaveIncorrectSuffixMessageMemberNewerVersion
data.value: Either replace the suffix '{0}' in member name {1} with the suggested numeric alternate '2' or provide a more meaningful suffix that distinguishes it from the member it replaces.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotHaveIncorrectSuffixMessageTypeNewerVersion
data.value: Either replace the suffix '{0}' in type name {1} with the suggested numeric alternate '2' or provide a more meaningful suffix that distinguishes it from the type it replaces.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotHaveIncorrectSuffixMessageMemberWithAlternate
data.value: Either replace the suffix '{0}' in member name '{1}' with the suggested alternate '{2}' or remove the suffix completely.

data.name: FlagsEnumsShouldHavePluralNamesTitle
data.value: Flags enums should have plural names

data.name: FlagsEnumsShouldHavePluralNamesDescription
data.value: A public enumeration has the System.FlagsAttribute attribute, and its name does not end in ""s"". Types that are marked by using FlagsAttribute have names that are plural because the attribute indicates that more than one value can be specified.

data.name: FlagsEnumsShouldHavePluralNamesMessage
data.value: Flags enums should have plural names

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotMatchKeywordsTitle
data.value: Identifiers should not match keywords

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotMatchKeywordsDescription
data.value: A namespace name or a type name matches a reserved keyword in a programming language. Identifiers for namespaces and types should not match keywords that are defined by languages that target the common language runtime.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotMatchKeywordsMessageMemberParameter
data.value: In virtual/interface member {0}, rename parameter {1} so that it no longer conflicts with the reserved language keyword '{2}'. Using a reserved keyword as the name of a parameter on a virtual/interface member makes it harder for consumers in other languages to override/implement the member.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotMatchKeywordsMessageMember
data.value: Rename virtual/interface member {0} so that it no longer conflicts with the reserved language keyword '{1}'. Using a reserved keyword as the name of a virtual/interface member makes it harder for consumers in other languages to override/implement the member.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotMatchKeywordsMessageType
data.value: Rename type {0} so that it no longer conflicts with the reserved language keyword '{1}'. Using a reserved keyword as the name of a type makes it harder for consumers in other languages to use the type.

data.name: IdentifiersShouldNotMatchKeywordsMessageNamespace
data.value: Rename namespace {0} so that it no longer conflicts with the reserved language keyword '{1}'. Using a reserved keyword as the name of a namespace makes it harder for consumers in other languages to use the namespace.

data.name: OnlyFlagsEnumsShouldHavePluralNamesTitle
data.value: Only FlagsAttribute enums should have plural names

data.name: OnlyFlagsEnumsShouldHavePluralNamesDescription
data.value: Naming conventions dictate that a plural name for an enumeration indicates that more than one value of the enumeration can be specified at the same time.

data.name: OnlyFlagsEnumsShouldHavePluralNamesMessage
data.value: Only FlagsAttribute enums should have plural names

data.name: PropertyNamesShouldNotMatchGetMethodsTitle
data.value: Property names should not match get methods

data.name: PropertyNamesShouldNotMatchGetMethodsDescription
data.value: The name of a public or protected member starts with ""Get"" and otherwise matches the name of a public or protected property. ""Get"" methods and properties should have names that clearly distinguish their function.

data.name: PropertyNamesShouldNotMatchGetMethodsMessage
data.value: The property name '{0}' is confusing given the existence of method '{1}'. Rename or remove one of these members.

data.name: TypeNamesShouldNotMatchNamespacesTitle
data.value: Type names should not match namespaces

data.name: TypeNamesShouldNotMatchNamespacesDescription
data.value: Type names should not match the names of namespaces that are defined in the .NET Framework class library. Violating this rule can reduce the usability of the library.

data.name: TypeNamesShouldNotMatchNamespacesMessageDefault
data.value: The type name {0} conflicts in whole or in part with the namespace name '{1}'. Change either name to eliminate the conflict.

data.name: TypeNamesShouldNotMatchNamespacesMessageSystem
data.value: The type name {0} conflicts in whole or in part with the namespace name '{1}' defined in the .NET Framework. Rename the type to eliminate the conflict.

data.name: ParameterNamesShouldMatchBaseDeclarationTitle
data.value: Parameter names should match base declaration

data.name: ParameterNamesShouldMatchBaseDeclarationDescription
data.value: Consistent naming of parameters in an override hierarchy increases the usability of the method overrides. A parameter name in a derived method that differs from the name in the base declaration can cause confusion about whether the method is an override of the base method or a new overload of the method.

data.name: ParameterNamesShouldMatchBaseDeclarationMessage
data.value: Parameter names should match base declaration

data.name: UsePreferredTermsTitle
data.value: Use preferred terms

data.name: UsePreferredTermsDescription
data.value: The name of an externally visible identifier includes a term for which an alternative, preferred term exists. Alternatively, the name includes the term ""Flag"" or ""Flags"".

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageAssembly
data.value: Replace the term '{0}' in assembly name {1} with the preferred alternate '{2}'.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageNamespace
data.value: Replace the term '{0}' in namespace name '{1}' with the preferred alternate '{2}'.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageMemberParameter
data.value: In member {0}, replace the term '{1}' in parameter name {2} with the preferred alternate '{3}'.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageDelegateParameter
data.value: In delegate {0}, replace the term '{1}' in parameter name {2} with the preferred alternate '{3}'.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageTypeTypeParameter
data.value: On type {0}, replace the term '{1}' in generic type parameter name {2} with the preferred alternate '{3}'.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageMethodTypeParameter
data.value: On method {0}, replace the term '{1}' in generic type parameter name {2} with the preferred alternate '{3}'.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageType
data.value: Replace the term '{0}' in type name {1} with the preferred alternate '{2}'.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageMember
data.value: Replace the term '{0}' in member name {1} with the preferred alternate '{2}'.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageAssemblyNoAlternate
data.value: Replace the term '{0}' in assembly name {1} with an appropriate alternate or remove it entirely.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageNamespaceNoAlternate
data.value: Replace the term '{0}' in namespace name '{1}' with an appropriate alternate or remove it entirely.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageMemberParameterNoAlternate
data.value: In member {0}, replace the term '{1}' in parameter name {2} with an appropriate alternate or remove it entirely.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageDelegateParameterNoAlternate
data.value: In delegate {0}, replace the term '{1}' in parameter name {2} with an appropriate alternate or remove it entirely.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageTypeTypeParameterNoAlternate
data.value: On type {0}, replace the term '{1}' in generic type parameter name {2} with an appropriate alternate or remove it entirely.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageMethodTypeParameterNoAlternate
data.value: On method {0}, replace the term '{1}' in generic type parameter name {2} with an appropriate alternate or remove it entirely.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageTypeNoAlternate
data.value: Replace the term '{0}' in type name {1} with an appropriate alternate or remove it entirely.

data.name: UsePreferredTermsMessageMemberNoAlternate
data.value: Replace the term '{0}' in member name {1} with an appropriate alternate or remove it entirely.

data.name: OverrideEqualsAndOperatorEqualsOnValueTypesTitle
data.value: Override equals and operator equals on value types

data.name: OverrideEqualsAndOperatorEqualsOnValueTypesDescription
data.value: For value types, the inherited implementation of Equals uses the Reflection library and compares the contents of all fields. Reflection is computationally expensive, and comparing every field for equality might be unnecessary. If you expect users to compare or sort instances, or to use instances as hash table keys, your value type should implement Equals.

data.name: OverrideEqualsAndOperatorEqualsOnValueTypesMessageEquals
data.value: {0} should override Equals.

data.name: OverrideEqualsAndOperatorEqualsOnValueTypesMessageOpEquality
data.value: {0} should override the equality (==) and inequality (!=) operators.

data.name: PropertiesShouldNotReturnArraysTitle
data.value: Properties should not return arrays

data.name: PropertiesShouldNotReturnArraysDescription
data.value: Arrays that are returned by properties are not write-protected, even when the property is read-only. To keep the array tamper-proof, the property must return a copy of the array. Typically, users will not understand the adverse performance implications of calling such a property.

data.name: PropertiesShouldNotReturnArraysMessage
data.value: Properties should not return arrays

data.name: AssembliesShouldHaveValidStrongNamesTitle
data.value: Assemblies should have valid strong names

data.name: AssembliesShouldHaveValidStrongNamesDescription
data.value: The strong name protects clients from unknowingly loading an assembly that has been tampered with. Assemblies without strong names should not be deployed outside very limited scenarios. If you share or distribute assemblies that are not correctly signed, the assembly can be tampered with, the common language runtime might not load the assembly, or the user might have to disable verification on his or her computer.

data.name: AssembliesShouldHaveValidStrongNamesMessageNoStrongName
data.value: Sign {0} with a strong name key.

data.name: AssembliesShouldHaveValidStrongNamesMessageNotValid
data.value: Verify that {0} has a valid strong name before deploying.

data.name: OverrideGetHashCodeOnOverridingEqualsTitle
data.value: Override GetHashCode on overriding Equals

data.name: OverrideGetHashCodeOnOverridingEqualsDescription
data.value: GetHashCode returns a value, based on the current instance, that is suited for hashing algorithms and data structures such as a hash table. Two objects that are the same type and are equal must return the same hash code.

data.name: OverrideGetHashCodeOnOverridingEqualsMessage
data.value: Override GetHashCode on overriding Equals

data.name: OverrideEqualsOnOverloadingOperatorEqualsTitle
data.value: Override Equals on overloading operator equals

data.name: OverrideEqualsOnOverloadingOperatorEqualsDescription
data.value: A public type implements the equality operator but does not override Object.Equals.

data.name: OverrideEqualsOnOverloadingOperatorEqualsMessage
data.value: Override Equals on overloading operator equals

data.name: OverrideEqualsOnOverloadingOperatorEqualsCodeActionTitle
data.value: Override object.Equals

data.name: OverrideGetHashCodeOnOverridingEqualsCodeActionTitle
data.value: Override object.GetHashCode

data.name: MakeExceptionPublic
data.value: Make exception public

data.name: InterfaceMethodsShouldBeCallableByChildTypesFix1
data.value: Make '{0}' protected.

data.name: InterfaceMethodsShouldBeCallableByChildTypesFix2
data.value: Change '{0}' to a public interface implementation.

data.name: InterfaceMethodsShouldBeCallableByChildTypesFix3
data.value: Make the containing type '{0}' sealed.

data.name: StaticHolderTypeIsNotStatic
data.value: Type '{0}' is a static holder type but is neither static nor NotInheritable

data.name: StaticHolderTypesShouldBeStaticOrNotInheritable
data.value: Static holder types should be Static or NotInheritable

data.name: MakeClassStatic
data.value: Make Class Static

data.name: OverrideObjectEqualsMessage
data.value: Type {0} should override Equals because it implements IEquatable<T>

data.name: OverrideObjectEqualsTitle
data.value: Override Object.Equals(object) when implementing IEquatable<T>

data.name: UseIntegralOrStringArgumentForIndexersDescription
data.value: Indexers, that is, indexed properties, should use integer or string types for the index. These types are typically used for indexing data structures and increase the usability of the library. Use of the Object type should be restricted to those cases where the specific integer or string type cannot be specified at design time. If the design requires other types for the index, reconsider whether the type represents a logical data store. If it does not represent a logical data store, use a method.

data.name: UseIntegralOrStringArgumentForIndexersMessage
data.value: Use Integral Or String Argument For Indexers

data.name: UseIntegralOrStringArgumentForIndexersTitle
data.value: Use Integral Or String Argument For Indexers

data.name: DoNotDirectlyAwaitATaskDescription
data.value: While authoring a library where the consumer is not known and when there is no need for a SynchronizationContext, consider using ConfigureAwait(false). Otherwise, the consumers of the library may face deadlocks by consuming the asynchronous methods in a blocking fashion.

data.name: DoNotDirectlyAwaitATaskMessage
data.value: Do not directly await a Task without calling ConfigureAwait

data.name: DoNotDirectlyAwaitATaskTitle
data.value: Do not directly await a Task

data.name: AppendConfigureAwaitFalse
data.value: Append .ConfigureAwait(false)
